Title.En: Adapting to Climate Change with Spatial Engineering

NoteLiteral.En:
There are no explicit domain prerequisites, but an open attitude towards wicked problems, interdisciplinary team work and international competences are required. Therefore a letter of motivation and a CV is needed from each applicant. Because of the internationalisation aspects of the course, we will aim for at least one candidate per university from which we receive applications. If availability permits, additional candidates from the same university can be admitted.

You will receive the result of your application soon after the application deadline (1st of October). If you are accepted and you’ve accepted the digital offer yourself too, more information will follow to make sure you’ll get access to everything you need.

Description.En:
The whole world is confronted with the effects of a changing climate. The challenge is how we deal with this situation. So how big is the problem in the city under study? What is at risk, and why? What is being done? What will happen if nothing is done? What would be the effect of adaptation measures?

In this course we follow the conceptual framework on risk defined by IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, www.ipcc.ch), where risk is at the centre. [Figure 1](https://www.ipcc.ch/report/managing-the-risks-of-extreme-events-and-disasters-to-advance-climate-change-adaptation/summary-for-policymakers/spm_fig1/) presents this framework, where three core concepts of weather and climate, exposure and vulnerability interact (IPCC, 2014). The risk of climate-related impacts results from the interaction of climate-related hazards (including weather and climatic events and their trends) with the vulnerability and exposure of human and natural systems. Changes in both the climate system (left) and socioeconomic processes including adaptation and mitigation (right) are drivers for changes in hazard, exposure, and vulnerability (IPCC, 2014).

There are options for risk reduction through adaptation, because adaptation measures can reduce risk by addressing one or more of the three risk factors: vulnerability, exposure, and/or hazard.This can be achieved through various policy and action choices. A visualisation of this process is in [Figure 2.](https://www.ipcc.ch/srocc/chapter/technical-summary/ts-0-introduction/ipcc-srocc-ts_4/) Risk reduction measures through adaptation (Source: IPCC 2019).

The three core concepts of hazard, exposure and vulnerability can be linked to the three core domains of Spatial Engineering: Hazard - Technical Engineering, Vulnerability - Spatial Information Science, and Exposure - Spatial Planning and Governance.

Title.En: Technical Engineering: Describe cycles of nutrients, water and carbon and underlying principles

NoteLiteral.En: Describe cycles of nutrients, water and carbon and underlying principles such as conservation of mass and energy (Process thinking and conceptualization).

Title.En: Spatial Information Science: Apply basic statistical methods to geographic data to gain insights

NoteLiteral.En: Apply basic statistical methods to geographic data to gain insights.

Title.En: General: Identify and describe gaps in your knowledge

NoteLiteral.En: Identify and describe gaps in your knowledge (related to the three core knowledge domains of spatial engineering, see below)

Title.En: General: Plan, execute and reflect on the learning process needed to bridge the gap

PrefLabel.En: evaluate data, information and digital content
respect the diversity of cultural values and norms

NoteLiteral.En: Plan, execute and reflect on the learning process needed to bridge the gap.

Title.En: Technical Engineering: Apply probability density functions and concepts of correlations & regression

NoteLiteral.En: Apply probability density functions and concepts of correlations and regressions (Stochasticity) to estimations of relevant parameters of earth system processes.

Title.En: Technical Engineering: Apply parameter uncertainty to make interpretations

NoteLiteral.En: Apply parameter uncertainty like variability, RMSE and R2, to make interpretations of outputs of models that simulate earth system processes (Parameter uncertainty).

Title.En: General: Integrate knowledge formulating an actionable challenge using the CBL for M-SE approach

NoteLiteral.En: Integrate knowledge formulating an actionable challenge using the Challenge Based Learning for M-SE approach

Title.En: Technical Engineering: Apply schematizing complex systems using existing techniques

NoteLiteral.En: Apply schematizing complex systems using existing techniques to capture them in equations (System thinking and model conceptualization).

Title.En: Spatial Planning for Governance: Describe and explain theory and context of spatial planning

NoteLiteral.En:
Theory and context
- Describe the evolution of spatial planning theory and practice and how these relate to notions of sustainable development and resilience.
- Explain the political, legal and institutional context of a spatial planning situation.

Title.En: Spatial Planning for Governance: Analysis of a planning situation

NoteLiteral.En:
Analysis of a planning situation
- Analyse a given spatial planning problem/situation, identifying key stakeholders and their interests.
- Describe the trade-offs between competing interests in a given spatial planning situation.

Title.En: Spatial Planning for Governance: Recommend evaluation and future needs

NoteLiteral.En:
Recommend evaluation and future needs
- Elaborate on ways to measure to guide, monitor and evaluate the realisation of spatial plans.

Title.En: Spatial Planning for Governance: Discuss how spatial analysis can assist

NoteLiteral.En: Discuss how spatial analysis can assist in anticipating future needs and emerging issues in society.

Title.En: Spatial Planning for Governance: Advice on a planning situation

NoteLiteral.En:
Advise on a planning situation
- Develop and present a concept plan for addressing a given spatial planning situation.

Title.En: Spatial Information Science: Conceptualize and represent the real world in digital geospatial data

NoteLiteral.En: Conceptualize and represent the real world in digital geospatial data.

Title.En: Spatial Information Science: Identify and apply multiple methods in a GIS

NoteLiteral.En: Identify and apply methods for the exploration, analysis, integration, synthesis and presentation of digital spatial data and imagery in a geographic information system (GIS).

Title.En: Adapting to Climate Change with Spatial Engineering
Adapting to Climate Change with Spatial Engineering

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
The study unit is an entire UT-quartile, for which you can be awarded 15 EC.

The course is fully online, and requires a time investment equal to 15 EC (with 28 hours per EC). This is a full time commitment for a 10 week period. There are a number of online meet-ups planned for the course that require attendance, although these differ per core knowledge track that you follow. Besides there are group meetings planned for the challenge, where your commitment and availability will also affect your fellow students. The exact moments of the meetings will be made available in the course of November. This will entail roughly 3 to 4 1-hour meetings throughout the week. In case of unavailability to attend any of the meetings, early contact with the coordinator to see how to moderate for this is at the responsibility of the student.

The 15 ECs are awarded to students who have: 

1. completed all assessments,
2. earned a pass mark all non-graded assessments and
3. earned a total weighed mark higher than the defined threshold.

The total mark is composed of two independent assessments: the core knowledge test (75%) and the actionable challenge essay (25%).
Help the city of Valencia (Spain) to adjust sustainably to climate change with Spatial Engineering

Are you passionate about solving the world's biggest challenges, like climate change, food insecurity, or biodiversity loss? If you're ready to make a real difference, this is the course for you! The world needs Spatial Engineers—innovative thinkers who can bridge multiple disciplines and master the art of spatial data to tackle these wicked problems head-on.


This dynamic course will empower you to become a Spatial Engineer by working on a real-world case study focused on climate change. Through a challenge-based approach, you'll not only develop an actionable plan for climate adaptation but also dive deep into the three core knowledge areas of Spatial Engineering: Spatial Information Science (SIS), Spatial Planning for Governance (SPG), and Technical Engineering (TE).

Here’s what you can expect:


1. Challenge-Based Learning: Engage in a hands-on challenge that will enhance your ability to integrate knowledge across disciplines. This experience is an introduction into the learning environment of the master’s programme Spatial Engineering as well (https://www.utwente.nl/en/education/master/programmes/spatial-engineering/).


2. Core Knowledge Mastery: Choose one of the three essential pillars of Spatial Engineering (SIS, TE, or SPG) and build a strong foundation in that area, especially if it's new to you.


With expert guidance you’ll choose one of the 3 core knowledge areas, and it will be one you’re not yet familiar with. Join us and start shaping a sustainable future today!

There are no explicit domain prerequisites, but an open attitude towards wicked problems, interdisciplinary team work and international competences are required. Therefore a letter of motivation and a CV is needed from each applicant. Because of the internationalisation aspects of the course, we will aim for at least one candidate per university from which we receive applications. If availability permits, additional candidates from the same university can be admitted. If needed, additional information of applicants/applications can be asked by the teamchers. You will receive the result of your application soon after the application deadline (1st of October). If you are accepted and you’ve accepted the digital offer yourself too, more information will follow to make sure you’ll get access to everything you need.
